@graph.reasoning: Petitioners claim that the implicit exemption applies only to labor-management agreements. The Government argues that the exemption should terminate at the point of impasse.
Petitioners deduce from case law language that the exemption applies only to labor-management agreements.
Petitioners deduce from case law language that the exemption applies only to labor-management agreements.
Petitioners deduce from case law language that the exemption applies only to labor-management agreements.
Petitioners cannot rescue their principle by claiming that the exemption applies only insofar as both labor and management consent to those understandings.

@graph.cite: Hi-Way Billboards, Inc., 206 N. L. R. B. 22 (1973)
@graph.reasoning: Petitioners cannot save their principle by weakening it, as by requiring union consent only to the multi-employer bargaining process itself.

@graph.cite: Weyerhaeuser Co., 166 N. L. R. B. 299 (1967)
@graph.reasoning: Petitioners cannot save their principle by weakening it, as by requiring union consent only to the multi-employer bargaining process itself.

@graph.cite: Worldwide Detective Bureau, 296 N. L. R. B. 148 (1989)
@graph.reasoning: The duty to bargain survives; employers must stand ready to resume collective bargaining.
Employers, however, are not completely free at impasse to act independently.
Labor law permits employers, after impasse, to engage in considerable joint behavior, including joint lockouts and replacement hiring.

@graph.cite: Gordon v. New York Stock Exchange, Inc., 422 U. S. 659 (1975)
@graph.reasoning: This Court has implied antitrust immunities that extend beyond statutorily required joint action to joint action that a statute 'expressly or impliedly allows or assumes must also be immune.'
